body:
@markdroth "Create a call to balancer" referes to [`query_for_backends_locked`](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/30b4e74296e612ee404707c8b61b4fc11ba6aadc/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/grpclb.c#L1441) right? Is this call going to a specific balancer which is a result of pick_first, or does this call contain the pick_first logic? I think I asked David a similar question yesterday and the answer is the latter. Then through which trace can I find the n-to-1 pick_fist logic?

That is what makes me keep clicking and wondering. Because I was thinking that I should use fallback only after all the balancer candidates are tried but unreachable (timeout), but I can't find the related code. Maybe I was thinking too much because I should treat `query_for_backends_locked` as an RPC with the pick_first part hidden. Now that I'm going to use a new fallback timer which is set when I start querying the backends, it seems that I won't depend on the query details anymore, which is good!

Yes, `query_for_backends_locked()` is the function that starts the LB call.  Note that the communication with the balancer is basically a recursive use of the C-core API -- we create a channel and send a call on it as if we were any other user of C-core; the fact that we happen to be inside of C-core itself is mostly irrelevant.  As a result, the pick_first details for the LB channel do not need to be handled in the grpclb code, because the LB channel will have its own client_channel filter with its own LB policy (which happens to be pick_first).

Note that the intent of the C-core API is to hide the details of load balancing from the application.  The application cares about how long it takes to get a response, not about how many servers we tried to contact during that time.  Accordingly, I do not think we should care about the details of the pick_first policy in the LB channel.  If we say that we want to use the fallback if we haven't gotten a balancer response within (e.g.) 5 seconds, then it doesn't matter whether we've tried one balancer or 100 balancers within those 5 seconds; the result is the same.
The setter and test commits are tentative. I pushed them for easier discussion.

Why would the picks be [pending](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/641eeccfdc1c957037ca5040e9125c788de36100/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/grpclb.c#L1619) if we receive a empty `serverlist`. 

Even though the previous `serverlist` is destroyed, the `rr_policy` is not destroyed. Wouldn't the picks use the old `rr_policy`?

> Why would the picks be [pending](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/641eeccfdc1c957037ca5040e9125c788de36100/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/grpclb.c#L1619) if we receive a empty `serverlist`. 
> 
> Even though the previous `serverlist` is destroyed, the `rr_policy` is not destroyed. Wouldn't the picks use the old `rr_policy`?

I think the log message on that line is a little misleading.  It's referring to the case where we have not yet received a serverlist before.  If we have previously received a serverlist, then you are correct that it will continue to use the old serverlist.  Feel free to update the log message.

In the test, the numbers of requests received by the backends are wrong. After `serverlist` replaces fallback, the pick for the backend returned by the balancer which has the smallest index will go to the backend returned by the resolver which has the smallest index. This wrong behavior remains even when the second call is delayed after `kServerlistDelayMs * 3`. I'm not sure whether this is caused by asynchronization.
